questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a history of liver cirrhosis presents to the emergency department with hematemesis and signs of shock. He is diagnosed with acute variceal bleeding. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management step for this patient?

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Administer intravenous vasopressin and initiate fresh frozen plasma transfusion

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with alcoholic cirrhosis presents to the emergency department with confusion, disorientation, and asterixis. His family reports increasing drowsiness and difficulty concentrating over the past few days. Investigations reveal normal electrolytes and elevated ammonia levels. What is the most appropriate initial treatment to lower ammonia?
questions.explanation:
Hepatic Encephalopathy

Etiopathogenesis
  • It is a complication of chronic liver disease that leads to impaired brain function as a result of liver failure.
  • It is also called as portosystemic encephalopathy.
  • Ammonia is a gut-derived neurotoxin that is not detoxified into urea and bypasses the liver due to portosystemic shunting and decreased hepatic mass, allowing it to enter the bloodstream and impact the brain.


 

Types

Type A is caused by acute liver failure & cerebral oedema is a common side effect of this type.

Type B is caused by portosystemic shunting (can be due to TIPS also)

Type C is due to chronic liver failure.













 

Clinical manifestations

Grade 0 - alterations are seen in neuropsychological tests, but only minimal symptomatic changes are evident in

  • Short-term memory,
  • Reaction time or
  • Concentration.

Grade 1:

  • Mood changes like anxiety, euphoria;
  • Memory trouble,
  • Trivial lack of awareness,
  • Difficulty with addition and subtraction,
  • Impaired sleep pattern.

Grade 2:

  • Personality changes
  • Lethargy & apathy
  • Behavior changes
  • Dysarthria
  • Disorientation for time

Grade 3:

  • Severe confusion, delirium
  • Disorientation to place
  • Drowsiness
  • Bizarre behavior
  • Asterixis

Grade 4: Coma (total loss of consciousness)

Grade 0,1 are considered convert or minimal hepatic encephalopathy, and grades 2,3,4 are overt hepatic encephalopathy with evident symptoms.

Investigations
  • Psychometric tests
  • Complete clinical evaluation
  • Blood investigations like LFT
  • Doppler ultrasound to evaluate the liver
  • EEG & MRI to assess brain activity

Management
  • Lactulose
  • Rifaximin (Option C) reduces ammonia production; it is an adjunctive therapy in patients who do not tolerate lactulose.
  • Neomycin is an alternative to Rifaximin.
  • Branched-chain amino acids and probiotics
  • Zinc supplementation, used as adjunct therapy (Option B)
  • Restricted protein intake was used in the past but is not commonly used due to its risk of malnutrition outweighs the benefits (Option A)
  • IV hydration is a vital supportive measure

questions.text: A 62-year-old male with a history of cirrhosis due to chronic hepatitis C presents with worsening abdominal distension, jaundice, and decreased urine output over the past week. He exhibits signs of confusion and ascites resistant to diuretics. Laboratory tests reveal a serum creatinine level of 2.5 mg/dL. Given this presentation, which of the following is the most definitive management of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Hepatorenal Syndrome (HRS)

Description

A functional renal failure resulting from advanced cirrhosis or acute liver failure without any underlying renal pathology.

Mechanism

  • Vasodilatory prostaglandins (PGE2 and PGI2) enhance renal blood flow and increase glomerular filtration rate to maintain perfusion, while in hepatosplenomegaly:

 
  • The cirrhotic liver produces endothelin-1, resulting in kidney injury, as:

Criteria

  • Refractory ascites (predispose to HRS)
  • Serum creatinine >1.5 mg% (progressive rise)
  • Stop diuretics (causes dehydration)
  • Volume expansion (volume given along with albumin will increase urine output)
  • No shock (but vitals monitoring is required)
  • No nephrotoxic drug exposure
  • No history of parenchymal disease (ruled out by imaging like ultrasound)

Types

Type I HRS or HRS-Acute Kidney Injury (AKI)

  • Progressive oliguria (renal function impairment) (Option B)
  • Rapid rise of the serum creatinine
  • Very poor prognosis

Type II HRS or HRS Non-Acute Kidney Injury (NAKI)

  • Associated with refractory ascites
  • Gradual increase in serum creatinine (moderate and stable)
  • Better prognosis.

Clinical features

  • History of chronic liver disease
  • Ascites (refractory or tense).
  • Respiratory distress (shortness of breath)
  • Variceal bleeding (hematemesis)
  • Deranged vitals
  • Decreased urine output or anuria

Management

  • Definitive treatment: Orthoptic liver transplant (OLT)
  • Pharmacological treatment: Following drugs can be used
    • Albumin infusion with vasoconstrictors (terlipressin, octreotide, midodrine) (Option C & D)
    • Norepinephrine can also be used.
    • Hemodialysis is not used mostly as it does not improve the outcome of the condition (Option A)

questions.text: A 62-year-old male with malnutrition and alcoholic liver disease presents with increasing abdominal distension, shortness of breath, fever, and significant weight loss. The ascitic fluid shows a neutrophil count greater than 250/μL. Which of the following statements about this condition are true? 1. Ascitic fluid appears transparent 2. Most commonly caused by Escherichia coli 3. Cefotaxime can be used for treatment 4. Norfloxacin administration may help to prevent it
questions.explanation:
Description

A severe complication of ascites, characterised by spontaneous infection of the ascitic fluid without an intra-abdominal source.

Causative organism
  • Escherichia coli (most common) and other gut bacteria (Statement 2)
  • Gram-positive bacteria (Streptococcus viridans, Staphylococcus aureus, and Enterococcus)

Source of infection

  

Clinical features
  • Worsening of ascites
  • Fever, nausea, vomiting
  • Increase in abdominal girth
  • Encephalopathy

Diagnosis

Ascitic fluid analysis shows:

  • Turbid appearance (Statement 1)
  • Neutrophil count >250/μL
  • Culture and gram satins reveal the causative organisms

Management

IV 3rd generation cephalosporins (cefotaxime) for 5 days (Statement 3)

Prevention

  • Paracentesis within 12 hours of hospital admission
  • Norfloxacin administration (cirrhotic patients with an episode of SBP) (Statement 4)
  • Quinolone antibiotic prophylaxis (recurrent episodes of SBP in variceal bleeding).

questions.explanation:
Causes of Cirrhosis

1. Micronodular Cirrhosis: Characterised by uniform nodules <3 mm in size. Commonly associated with:

  • Alcoholic Liver Disease
  • Chronic Biliary Obstruction and Cholangitis:
    • Primary Biliary Cholangitis (PBC)
    • Secondary Biliary Cholangitis
  • Hemochromatosis
  • Non-cirrhotic Portal Fibrosis (NCPF)
 

2. Macronodular Cirrhosis: Characterised by variable nodules >3 mm in size. Associated with:

  • Viral Hepatitis:
  • Hepatitis B
  • Hepatitis C
  • Hepatitis D
  • Autoimmune Hepatitis
  • Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) (linked to obesity and metabolic syndrome)
  • Wilson Disease
  • Alpha-1 Antitrypsin Deficiency
  • Cystic Fibrosis
  • Cryptogenic Cirrhosis

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with a history of alcohol use and chronic hepatitis presents with abdominal swelling, fatigue, difficulty eating, dark stools, and black vomitus. Examination shows splenomegaly, ascites and dilated veins around the umbilicus. Which of the following is the investigation of choice for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Investigation

Purpose/Findings

Ultrasonography

Visualises features like splenomegaly and collateral vessels; can identify causes like liver disease or portal vein thrombosis.

Doppler Ultrasound

Investigation of choice to measure pressure gradient.

Hepatic venous pressure gradient (HVPG) > 5 mm Hg indicates portal hypertension.

Blood Counts (CBC) 

(Option B ruled out)

First biochemical sign is thrombocytopenia (due to hypersplenism).
It also shows leukopenia and anaemia.

Endoscopy

(Option A ruled out)

Used to check for gastro-oesophageal varices.

CT and MRI Scan (Option A ruled out)

Assess the extent of portal vein thrombosis and evaluate hepatic vein patency.

HVPG Measurement

It is rarely performed by interventional radiology to measure hepatic venous pressure gradient directly.

METAVIR score

Stage of fibrosis

F0

F1 (Option A)

Portal zone fibrosis (few)

F2 (Option B)

Portal zone fibrosis and occasional (few) bridging.

F3 (Option C)

Cirrhosis

Ishak Grade

Stage of fibrosis

0

2

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman with a history of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) presents for routine follow-up. She reports mild fatigue but denies significant abdominal pain or jaundice. On examination, she has no stigmata of chronic liver disease. The physician wants to assess the degree of liver fibrosis. Which of the following is the best non-invasive test to evaluate liver stiffness?
questions.explanation:
Non-invasive investigations for Cirrhosis

Fibrotest
  • This test assesses specific blood markers to determine cirrhosis,
  • Blood markers:
    • Bilirubin
    • Gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT)
    • Haptoglobin
    • Apolipoprotein A
    • α2 - Macroglobulin,

Serum electrophoresis

In chronic liver disease, this shows decreased albumin and elevated γ Globulin.

Live function test
  • LFTs are commonly used for screening liver health.
  • In chronic hepatitis, both ALT and AST are elevated, with ALT typically greater than AST (ALT > AST).
  • These tests also evaluate vital parameters such as bilirubin and albumin to assess liver function.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with a history of cirrhosis presents with increased fatigue, and examination reveals multiple vascular lesions on the skin. His liver function tests show significant elevations in AST and ALT. What is the primary pathophysiological mechanism responsible for the formation of these lesions in cirrhosis?
questions.correct_answer: D. Increased vascularity due to estrogen
questions.explanation:
Clinical signs & symptoms of Cirrhosis

Vague symptoms
  • Abdominal pain (in the right upper quadrant)
  • Fever
  • Nausea
  • Vomiting
  • Diarrhea
  • Anorexia

Palmar erythema

It is characterised by reddening of the palms due to increased estrogen levels from impaired liver function, which leads to vasodilation and increased blood flow and serves as an important clinical indicator of liver dysfunction.

Dupuytren's contracture

It happens due to thickening and shortening of the palmar fascia. It can start on the ring finger and involve the little finger.

Clubbing
  • Platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF) can be released, leading to tissue proliferation at the base of the nail. (Option C)
  • This results in a bulbous appearance, and it is not very specific as can be seen in other conditions.

Parotid enlargement

Especially in alcoholic cirrhosis, due to fat deposition in parotid glands, bilateral parotid enlargement can be appreciated.


 

Testicular atrophy
  • This can result from a combination of increased estrogen, decreased testosterone production and altered hormonal regulation
  • Other manifestations in male patients:
    • Gynecomastia,
    • Decreased body hair
    • Muscle wasting.

Jaundice

This occurs due to the liver's impaired ability to process and excrete bilirubin, resulting in its accumulation in the bloodstream.

Kayser–Fleischer rings

Seen in cirrhosis caused by Wilson’s disease, they are greenish-brown deposits of copper that form in the cornea due to affected copper metabolism.

Asterixis

It is flapping tremors of the hand commonly associated with hepatic encephalopathy.

Caput medusae

It is the appearance of engorged superficial veins on the abdominal wall and is a clinical sign of portal hypertension often seen in cirrhosis. (Option A)
